title: Frustrated Jeremy Corbyn insists Labour CAN win a snap election
text:

A frustrated Jeremy Corbyn insisted Labour CAN win a snap general election, today. 
In a prickly interview with the BBC’s Victoria Derbyshire, the Labour leader seemed initially reluctant to give a clear answer on the question. 
He was asked five times whether he thought Labour could win a snap poll, but insisted nobody can know the result of an election before the election. 
Instead, he repeatedly said Labour would “take our case to the British people”, urging Ms Derbyshire not to “underestimate the support for the Labour party ” and the “anger that is out there” about issues of social inequality. 
Finally, pressed for a yes or no answer, he fumed: “Listen, you’ve asked me the question many times. How many times do I have to tell you? We’re taking our case out there to win because we believe we can win.” 
It follows a string of disastrous polling numbers for Labour, with the Tories holding on to a 18 point lead. 
Ms Derbyshire asked Mr Corbyn about a quote from a Labour MP, who reportedly asked Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell at a Parliamentary Labour Party meeting last night: “Why is a former Tory Prime Minister more effective at attacking a Tory government than a Labour Shadow Chancellor”. Read More No, Jeremy Corbyn didn't forget to declare income in his tax return 
The jibe referred to John Major’s speech about Brexit last week. 
Corbyn insisted: “I’ve no idea who he or she is or why they said that. We are attacking this government on issues of health and social care. We’re attacking this government on issues of economic development. Of unemployment, of under-employment. Of zero hours contracts. Of insecurity of work. 
“We’re attacking this government on all these fronts. Because John Major is critical of the government over the European Union - so are we. 
“We have accepted the result of the referendum, but we also want to make sure there is a good, effective, tariff-free arrangement with Europe in the future.” Read More Jeremy Corbyn is a 'disaster' for Labour and should quit as leader, says Professor Stephen Hawking 
Asked if he would welcome William Hague’s idea of scrapping the Fixed-term Parliaments Act and calling for a snap election, he said Labour supported the Act, because it increased “stability in politics”. 
But he said if there was a proposal to get rid of it “I’m sure we’d consider it.” Read More 
Asked if he’d welcome a snap general election, he said: “I want to see a different government. I don’t want this government in office.” Like us on Facebook
